When this chapter begins, the PCs’ kingdom has grown to encompass the majority of the Stolen Lands. Pitax has been welcomed into the nation, and the people of the kingdom are finally able to relax after the trauma of war recedes. Of course, a new threat is about to strike, but since the kingdom building part of the campaign has more or less concluded, you can simply run this chapter as-is without having to catch the players up on their kingdom’s growth.

The Calm Before.name: Cisza przed burzą
The Calm Before.text:
The timing of when this chapter begins is left to you to decide. If the PCs’ kingdom hasn’t yet grown to span all four regions of the Stolen Lands, you’ll want to run a few more years of kingdom growth until their kingdom covers a wide enough area that when @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD] starts her assault, the PCs will be compelled to oppose her. Give them time to explore Candlemere, finish up lingering wilderness encounters, and pursue a few loose ends.

Nyrissa’s intrusion into the Stolen Lands can be thought of as a levee breaking. At first, the appalling weight of the First World strains at this levee like the weight of a mighty river straining to flood the adjacent kingdom. Early bloom events occur at a trickle as the First World seeps slowly into the region. These trickles quickly become full-fledged breaches as the blooms pour forth, and as these breaches grow, the danger grows as well, eventually culminating in the arrival of a deadly predator from the First World—the @UUID[.hWPTtnhym5ogqxSt].

You can use the following two quests to get the PCs started on preparing for Nyrissa’s attack on the Stolen Lands. The Houten Legacy in particular should be presented to the PCs, since obtaining a copy of @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg] before they enter Thousandbreaths can help to foreshadow @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v] of this chapter.

The Houten Legacy

  • 30 XP

Belinda Houten wants to leave a legacy; a resplendent theater dedicated to her family name. She possesses a book that a fortune-teller told her the leaders of the Stolen Lands would someday need to fulfill their destiny, but she won’t part with it until she has her buildings.

Source: Aristocrat Belinda Houten, who can live in any settlement with a Noble Villa.

Completion: Build a Theater and four Monuments in Belinda’s honor.

Reward: Belinda is as good as her word and presents the PCs with a mint-condition copy of @UUID[Item.3ezSi7MS1XA4RfcC] worth 5,000 gp. This book’s contents are presented as handouts @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg]; the book's @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg.JournalEntryPage.71I38vDWfJaf8A1g] presents a map of Thousandbreaths (see also the @UUID[Scene.UBHZsJUUrunIVYXl] scene).

A Heroic Challenge

  • 30 XP

Hailing from Pitax and long having a reputation as the city’s boldest and most successful dragonslayer, Aurex Thewsen is also an abrasive braggart. He recognizes the PCs as heroes but dares them to prove their mettle as dragonslayers and cement their legitimacy as true rulers of the Stolen Lands. Aurex himself has slain several noteworthy dragons in the River Kingdoms, but the legendary black dragon Ilthuliak eluded him. Defeating her would suffice, if the PCs were clever enough to find her and brave enough to confront her.

Source: Aurex Thewsen, Pitax’s greatest dragonslayer!

Completion: Slay @UUID[.C8iJTL8Fl1Vf7OxB] and bring back her head.

Reward: The PCs become famed dragonslayers, their names known throughout the land. The kingdom’s maximum Fame or Infamy (as appropriate) increases by 1, and Ilthuliak’s remains can be used to build a Monument in a settlement without needing to expend any resources. Aurex agrees to build a Tavern in Pitax and work there as a bartender for one year, telling every patron the story of that the PCs are the greatest dragonslayers in the Stolen Lands.

Evindra’s Warning.name: Evindra’s Warning
Evindra’s Warning.text:
The following assumes the PCs have earned @UUID[JournalEntry.yGGSDRma9yTWwdeo.JournalEntryPage.hApY4fHj30PWilNG]’s thanks and aid, but you can provide this information via any other supernatural NPC with whom the PCs may have forged a strong relationship.

Evindra warns the PCs as this chapter begins that powerful forces from the First World are likely to be drawn to the Stolen Lands soon, for she’d been charged with keeping Briar hidden by a mysterious agent of the Eldest named Weren, who told her it was important to keep Briar from the agents of the nymph queen Nyrissa. She blames herself for allowing the weapon to fall into Irovetti’s hands, and even though this didn’t result in the sword’s return to Nyrissa, the close call shames and distresses Evindra for some time. Evindra responds as follows to topics that the PCs are likely to ask about.

@UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]: Evindra began her watch over Briar seven decades ago. Weren told her the sword was valuable to an “upstart nymph” named Nyrissa—that Nyrissa desired the blade, and that the Eldest did not want her to have it. Evindra can explain to the PCs what Briar is currently capable of, and that more of its powers are likely to awaken the more it’s exposed to the raw energies of the First World or is used to slay denizens of that realm. While Evindra doesn’t know all of Briar’s potential powers, she does know that, fully awakened, the sword is both intelligent and a vorpal sword, among other things. Once capable of speech, Evindra notes, Briar itself may be able to tell them more.

@UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs.JournalEntryPage.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch]: Evindra doesn’t know much more about Weren. She doesn’t believe that’s his full name and, while he appeared to be an attractive fey man with pointed ears, orange eyes, and long fingers, the way his form shimmered a bit leads her to believe he had disguised his true form when he delivered Briar to her. She says that he was very persuasive in convincing her of how important it was to keep the sword hidden. She believed him when he said he served the direct interests of the Eldest, but the more the PCs suggest that maybe he tricked her or even used magic to compel her, the more suspicious she grows about “Weren.”

@UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD]: Evindra relates the legend of how Nyrissa fell in love with one of the Eldest and then how her resulting rise in power led her to proclaim herself one of the rulers of the First World. The other Eldest reacted poorly, first sending the jabberwock against her and then trying to rip her domain out from under her, but Nyrissa defeated the jabberwock and used a thousand promises of fey fealty to ward her domain. But when Nyrissa’s lover was exiled, she was punished. Evindra doesn’t know the details of that punishment, but she does know that Nyrissa still holds a grudge against the Eldest and suspects Briar has something to do with it.

Evindra knows that Nyrissa’s domain is called Thousandbreaths, and that it lies close to the Material Plane in the similarly named Thousand Voices, or Forest of Breath. She knows too that Nyrissa has long had an interest in the Stolen Lands, and that many of the region’s fey know of her and fear her; there are even rumors that the nymph queen walks the Stolen Lands now and then, visiting cruelties on those who annoy her and strange rewards upon those who please her. These rumors make Evindra suspect that there may be some physical connection between the Stolen Lands and the First World—and logic would dictate that a likely place for such a connection to exist would be the depths of the forest of Thousand Voices.

The Blooms Begin.name: The Blooms Begin
The Blooms Begin.text:
In previous chapters, the PCs could afford to take months or even years off during the course of play. If there are still parts of the Stolen Lands the PCs wish to explore, consider delaying this chapter until that itch for exploration is scratched, because once Nyrissa’s blooms begin to manifest, they come fast and furious. This is by design—the assault on the kingdom is meant to be swift, so the PCs should not have a lot of time to rebuild resources and recover between blooms.

The events in Part 1 take place over the course of a single month, with only a few days passing between each new manifestation of a bloom. Since a Kingdom turn lasts a month, this means that no kingdom management or development can occur during Part 1 once the blooms begin.

Assuming the PCs defeat all of the blooms and survive this month of destruction with their kingdom intact, the adventure and campaign can immediately return to a more laconic pace if you desire. After the month of destruction, if the PCs have not yet fully explored Thousandbreaths or defeated Nyrissa, they’ll be rewarded for enduring that month by being able to tackle @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v] and @UUID[.AhoW6h9pYiABWk5K] of this adventure at a pace of their own choosing—although if they take too long, you should feel free to have Nyrissa start a second or even a third round of blooms.

All of the events detailed in this part start with a date listed as “Day 1,” “Day 14,” “Day 27,” and so on. It’s convenient if you set Day 1 on the first day of the month, but it’s not required. If you start the month on a day other than the first, though, you should delay the next @UUID[JournalEntry.ufhwExwde2g3iEa7.JournalEntryPage.406nR8T69GIGW6bc], having it play out at the end of this part.

When a PC encounters a bloom, success on a @Check[type:nature|dc:36|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:34|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo] confirms that the incident is caused by a planar breach between the Material Plane and the First World, although the breach is not large or stable enough to allow creatures to cross between the planes. Learning the same information about a bloom the PCs have not personally visited is possible, but the DC is increased by 10.

Bloom Effects on the Kingdom

When a bloom manifests, it does so in a single hex somewhere in the Stolen Lands. Most blooms are assigned a type of hex that it can appear in—the exact hex in which the bloom appears is left to you to determine, although the hex containing the PCs’ capital should never be chosen. Once a bloom manifests, that hex is lost from the PCs’ kingdom (see @UUID[JournalEntry.ufhwExwde2g3iEa7.JournalEntryPage.kitlt28oPiGVyHCH] for the repercussions of losing a hex). If a bloom is defeated, the hex remains lost and must be reclaimed before it is returned to the PCs’ kingdom.

Once a bloom appears, it spreads at a rate of 1 hex per day into a single adjacent, unbloomed hex, determined randomly. The original hex always remains the core hex in which the mechanism for defeating the bloom remains. When a bloom is defeated, all hexes it has spread into revert to normal (but must be reclaimed individually).

Noticing the Blooms

Although a newly formed bloom is obvious to those in the hex in which it appears, it sometimes takes time for word to spread. In particular, the first bloom may well catch the PCs off guard as they’re unlikely to be expecting such an event.

If the PCs enter a hex containing a bloom, either on the day it manifests or thereafter, they automatically notice the bloom. Otherwise, each time a bloom manifests, use the secret Notice Bloom activity to determine how long it takes before news of the new bloom reaches the PCs’ attention. Once the PCs have learned of the first bloom, they can use the Bloom Watch downtime activity to actively search the Stolen Lands for undiscovered blooms.

Notice Bloom r

  • Secret

Trigger A bloom manifests in the Stolen Lands.

When a bloom manifests, its effects are not subtle. Nonetheless, it can take some time for witnesses to report the bloom to the PCs. When a bloom begins, roll a secret kingdom skill check to determine how long it takes before the PCs learn about it.

If the bloom manifests in an unclaimed hex, roll a @Check[type:exploration|dc:35|traits:action:notice-bloom|roller:party] check.

If the bloom manifests in a claimed hex, roll a @Check[type:defense|dc:30|traits:action:notice-bloom|roller:party] check; if the hex contains a settlement, the result is automatically improved by one degree of success.

If the bloom manifests in the kingdom’s capital, or in a hex that’s currently occupied by a PC, the check is automatically a critical success.

  • Critical Success The PCs automatically learn about the bloom the same day it manifests.

  • Success The PCs automatically learn about the bloom [[/gmroll 1d4]] days after it manifests.

  • Failure The PCs automatically learn about the bloom [[/gmroll 2d4]] days after it manifests.

  • Critical Failure The PCs won’t automatically learn about the bloom; they must discover it via the Bloom Watch activity or by entering the bloom’s hex.

Bloom Watch

  • Concentration
  • Downtime

You spend the day working with agents in your nation examining field reports, speaking with scouts, listening to rumors, interviewing allies, or researching with divination magic to try to pinpoint the locations of undiscovered blooms. Attempt a @Check[type:defense|dc:40|traits:action:bloom-watch|roller:party] or @Check[type:survival|dc:40|traits:action:bloom-watch] check, a @Check[type:intrigue|dc:36|traits:action:bloom-watch|roller:party] (expert) or @Check[type:perception|dc:36|traits:action:bloom-watch] (expert) check, or a @Check[type:magic|dc:32|traits:action:bloom-watch|roller:party] (master) or @Check[type:nature|dc:32|traits:action:bloom-watch] (master) check.

  • Critical Success Choose a hex on the map of the Stolen Lands. You discover the two closest undiscovered blooms to that hex. If there are no undiscovered blooms currently active, your research notes a growing magical energy in the hex where the next bloom will manifest. This doesn’t indicate when that bloom will occur, but it does allow the PCs to prepare to handle that bloom when it occurs (for example, if a PC is present in that hex when the bloom manifests, they automatically know it’s happening).

  • Success Choose a hex on the map of the Stolen Lands. You discover the two closest undiscovered blooms to that hex. If there are no undiscovered blooms currently active, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus on the next Notice Bloom reaction.

  • Failure If there are undiscovered blooms in claimed hexes, you discover the closest one to your location.

  • Critical Failure You fail to determine the location of any undiscovered blooms.

Defeating Blooms

As blooms manifest, the PCs can defeat them. The method of defeating each bloom is different. Once a bloom is defeated, the PCs can harvest special trophies that allow them to enter and navigate Thousandbreaths with increasing ease; they’ll need at least three different types of bloom trophy before they can even open the portal to Thousandbreaths at the start of @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v].

When the PCs defeat a bloom, the strange energies and First World power are released in a dramatic way. The energy suffusing the area rises up from the surrounding terrain in a vortex of green light and a high-pitched keening not unlike the sound of a mortally wounded rabbit or deer. This energy is eerie and disturbing, but ultimately harmless, and it disperses quickly. The majority of the energy returns to Thousandbreaths, though a number of objects at each bloom site are infused with a small bit of power turning them into bloom trophies—items that are magically linked to a specific area of Thousandbreaths. Each bloom encounter lists the type of object that becomes its bloom trophy along with its linked area. A dead creature that becomes a bloom trophy does not decay, cannot be transformed into an undead, and won’t be eaten by scavengers (such as maggots) for 100 days.

Bloom trophies radiate strong conjuration and transmutation magic. A successful DC 35 check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.eReSHVEPCsdkSL4G] allows a PC to note that the item has become infused with the bloom’s energies and now holds within it a magical link between the object and the First World. A character carrying a bloom trophy receives a +1 status bonus on attack rolls, weapon damage rolls, skill checks, saving throws, and ability checks while in the trophy’s linked area in Thousandbreaths.

Bloom Growth

While the exact nature of each bloom varies, all of them—save for the @UUID[.AMmC4r0Kija5A9XZ] (below) and @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB]—cause vegetation in their hexes to grow rampant and uncontrolled. These hexes are treated as difficult terrain as a result, and the DC of Survival checks attempted in them is increased by 5.

Day 1: The Whirling Lake.name: Day 1: The Whirling Lake
Day 1: The Whirling Lake.text:
Scene

@UUID[Scene.pl9Jhx5QomIaV5U8]

The first bloom is not a bloom of vegetation but a bloom of churning water. Unlike land-based blooms, which manifest as sudden tangles of overgrowth, this bloom manifests as a whirlpool of black water in one of the Stolen Lands’ lakes.

Location: This bloom can appear in any lake in the Stolen Lands. Its effects can spread only through water—it cannot spread into hexes that don’t contain water connected to the source bloom via a lake or river.

Bloom: The whirlpool is 500 feet across at the surface and reaches all the way down to the bottom of the lake where it leaves a 50-foot-diameter area of the lake bed exposed to the air. Any creature that enters the whirlpool must attempt a @Check[type:reflex|dc:38] save; on a failure, their turn immediately ends, they take [[/r 8d6[bludgeoning]]] damage (and accidentally ingest some of the water on a critical failure—see below), and they’re swept up by the vortex. While a creature is swept up, they rotate around the vortex and are essentially @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei] by the current. A creature can attempt a @Check[type:athletics|dc:38|traits:action-escape] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9] by swimming free of the current. Each time a creature ends its turn in the vortex, it must attempt a new @Check[type:reflex|dc:38] save to avoid damage and being swept up.

Eerie, silent black swans congregate in the waters surrounding the whirlpool; as they’re drawn into the vortex, they fly up into the air and settle down back in the water some distance away only to slowly drift back into the whirlpool. The swans are ill-tempered but otherwise normal. Attempts to communicate with them via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.BBvV7qoXGdw09q1C] or similar magic reveals that they fear the whirlpool because it’s loud and scary; they don’t have memories of their life in the similar lake in Thousandbreaths (@UUID[.hwO3Kbh0Izx5mQtF]). The swans are immune to the disease brought by the churning waters.

Anyone who drinks the water in this hex or any hex that the bloom has spread to is exposed to a 14th-level strain of blinding sickness (see the @UUID[Actor.L6ANJQoCyk5dWcdH]).

@UUID[Actor.L6ANJQoCyk5dWcdH]

Severe 17

A group of four extremely powerful elemental tsunamis swim and froth in the region surrounding the vortex. The elementals can move through the vortex with ease, ignoring its effects just as they ignore the swans and any animals of that size or smaller. They quickly move to attack larger creatures that approach, using Stealth for initiative as they split off from the whirlpool in their own vortex shapes and assume their natural forms: immense swanlike shapes of dark water.

If all four elementals are slain or banished from the Material Plane, the central vortex immediately collapses in on itself as the bloom vanishes. The resulting geyser of water calms quickly, and all the black swans die and bob to the surface.

@UUID[Item.U4QON5JFeGRdAZ3k]: Black swan carcasses, linked to the Lake of Midnight Swans (@UUID[.hwO3Kbh0Izx5mQtF]).

Day 3: Fey Warning.name: Day 3: Fey Warning
Day 3: Fey Warning.text:
Once the blooms begin, it is not only the PCs and the ordinary citizens of their kingdom that start to feel the deadly sting of Nyrissa’s wrath. The Stolen Lands have a vast population of fey, and many of them sense the disruption of the veil between the First World and the Material Plane when the first bloom begins. By this point in the campaign, the PCs have likely shown themselves to be reliable friends of fey who are in trouble, so these individuals may appeal to the PCs to help them just as their own citizens would. This may come in the form of fey they’ve known for a long time like Melianse and Tiressia asking what they make of troublesome signs in the natural world, or it may come from a fey they have not previously met who has strange tales of dangers unseen that foreshadows troubles to come, like Limm Ticklewing, who can seek out the PCs for aid.

The Pixie’s Sisters

  • Rare
  • 30 XP

Limm Ticklewing is worried for her six sisters, as a few weeks ago they were all captured by a “nasty wizard made of worms!” He and a “scary witch” put Limm’s sisters into a magical cage and gave it to a “big mean troll” before Limm was able to escape and hide. As she escaped, Limm stole a bag of shiny gems and stashed them in a safe place; if the PCs can rescue her sisters, she’ll give them one gem for each rescue.

Source: Limm Ticklewing, worried pixie.

Completion: Rescue Limm’s sisters from the @UUID[.Eg1AzaavQmg6VbK7] and return them to her at a place you mutually agree upon.

Reward: For each sister returned, Limm rewards the PCs with an emerald worth 2,000 gp.

Day 8: The Shrieking Children.name: Day 8: The Shrieking Children
Day 8: The Shrieking Children.text:
The sudden growth in this bloom consists of a foul tangle of enormous mushrooms, molds, and thick fibrous roots and vines that quickly start to choke out existing plant life. Along with this fungal bloom come swarms of bloodthirsty mandragoras.

Location: A forested hex in Zones 2–6 that does not contain a settlement.

Bloom: Thousands of four-inch-high mandragoras infest this bloom. Each of these misshapen plants looks vaguely humanoid, with tiny eyes, leaves for hair, and sharp wooden teeth. When the PCs notice the bloom, it’s likely due to reports of these creatures biting the ankles of livestock or children, chasing pets, or climbing up onto sleeping citizens to drink blood from exposed necks or arms.

@UUID[Actor.6BFUxkEBKPr89SNt]

Severe 17

The mandragora swarms sleep at night, but during the day anyone who enters the bloom can’t help but notice the countless tiny cries and whispers that emanate throughout the area. While there are tens of thousands of mandragoras in this bloom, the PCs need only defeat two swarms before the entire flood of tiny mandragoras shrieks and dies. Each mandragora swarm begins battle with a Piercing Shriek. It then swarms over as many foes as it can, chewing, draining blood, and leaving confused victims in its wake. The mandragora swarms fight until destroyed.

@UUID[Item.JKCns3BRL7EgQBM4]: Dead mandragoras, linked to the Fruiting Orchard (@UUID[.1pH3Z4bzZ12uCY78]).

Day 9: The Horned Hunters.name: Day 9: The Horned Hunters
Day 9: The Horned Hunters.text:
Nyrissa knows that Briar can slay her, and as this chapter of Kingmaker progresses, she becomes aware of rumors that the PCs have discovered the sword. This element, seemingly fitting so perfectly into the ancient visions she received of her own death, increasingly distresses her, and on day 9 of the month of destruction, she sends a group known as the Horned Hunt—the protectors and wardens of the realm of Thousandbreaths—into the Material Plane to find the PCs and secure the sword.

  • @UUID[Actor.OhuPV1g5LfejhtAz]
  • @UUID[Actor.kKH3uMHbVZQmEtxj]

Encounter

Severe 17

The Horned Hunt consists of a trio of jotund trolls led by a deadly satyr ranger known as the Horned Hunter. They first appear in the Stolen Lands deep in Thousand Voices at the Castle of Knives (encounter site @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9]) and immediately seek out the PCs, leaving devastation in their passing.

The Horned Hunter knows quite a bit about the PCs; assuming the PCs have displayed a tendency to protect their people, the Horned Hunter knows that the best way to lure the PCs into a conflict is to begin wreaking havoc to draw them out. If the PCs seem not to care about their people, the Horned Hunt either travels to the next bloom site to ambush the PCs when they come to defeat it, or they attempt to infiltrate the PCs’ homes when each of them is alone to try to take them down one at a time. How you use the Horned Hunt is up to you, but the PCs should first learn of their location and actions on this day.

When combat begins, the Horned Hunter Plays the Pipes after positioning himself to affect as many foes as possible. He then attacks with his bow, targeting one enemy at a time. Although his natural inclination is to fire upon humans before any other target, if it’s obvious who’s carrying Briar, he and his trolls focus their attacks on that character.

If the character carrying Briar is defeated, the Horned Hunter claims the sword as soon as he can, then uses @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.F1qxaqsEItmBura2] as soon as possible to make his way back to the Castle of Knives to deliver Briar to Nyrissa. See @UUID[.AhoW6h9pYiABWk5K] for details of what happens if Nyrissa gains control of Briar in this way.

Day 12: Nights of Dread.name: Day 12: Nights of Dread
Day 12: Nights of Dread.text:
The most insidious of the blooms does not manifest physically, but in the dreams of those it touches upon.

Location: This bloom manifests in the PCs’ capital. Unlike other blooms, this one does not physically change the region it influences or spread into neighboring hexes.

Bloom: This bloom’s effects manifest in the dead of night, at which point many who sleep in the hex suffer nightmares of being chased through the woods, being savaged by wild animals, and of being pursued by an immense dark bird whose wings blot out the stars.

In some cases, these dreams have a greater effect than merely unsettling sleep—for some, they become living nightmares that end with a real magical effect. On the first night, only one creature experiences a living nightmare. Each night it persists, it causes one additional creature to experience a living nightmare (so, two victims on the second day, three on the third, four on the fourth, and so on until the bloom is destroyed). The bloom targets PCs randomly if they sleep in the bloom hex, or random citizens if not (who are slain by the living nightmare). At your discretion, key NPCs or companions can be targeted, in which case you should have a player control the NPC and play out the bloom’s effects rather than having the NPC automatically slain.

When a character is targeted by a living nightmare, they endure the phantasmagoric visions and then awaken with a scream as the nightmare culminates in a powerful spell effect. You can use the table below to randomly determine what sort of nightmare and spell effect the character is targeted by or use these suggestions to create similar effects of your own design (note that all of these spells are ones that target a single creature). All of these spells are heightened to 9th level, have spell attack +30, and are DC 36.

@UUID[RollTable.RyETqIR5yFNv4BmP]
[[/r 1d8]]Spell EffectLiving Nightmare Description
1@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.dN8QBNuTiaBHCKUe]You are hunted by predators and wake as a harmless animal.
2@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.VosLNn2M8S7JH67D]You gaze upon something so horrific that you are blinded.
3@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.OsOhx3TGIZ7AhD0P]Your allies are possessed. Kill them before they kill you.
4@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.5BbU1V6wGSGbrmRD]Your thoughts are not your own, as if something else were thinking for you.
5@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.znv4ECL7ZtuiagtA]You are buried alive but remain aware as the years pass and you fossilize.
6@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.tlcrVRqW1MSKJ5IC]You are attacked by a frightening monster or your most fearful foe.
7@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.BKIet436snMNcnez]You endure an eternal blizzard after the world has frozen.
8@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.8kJbiBEjMWG4VUjs]The world around you keeps changing into different horrifying realities.

Regardless of the nature of the living nightmare a given victim endures, the living nightmares share a feature in common with the standard nightmares suffered by everyone in the bloom: the presence of an immense black bird that watches over the nightmare from the dark night skies above. This monstrous shape never takes direct action in the nightmares, but the dreamers always wake with the conviction that the bird caused the nightmare.

This shape is a creature called the @UUID[Actor.L3q7yQ0jKqH2IWy7], an immense avian that dwells in Thousandbreaths and directs the horrific nightmares from that realm (see @UUID[.VooytwmPZQrM1I7N]). A PC who experiences a nightmare can attempt a @Check[type:nature|dc:36|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check or @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo] to identify the Nightmare Rook as a mythological creature said to dwell in the First World; on a critical success, the character also remembers that a creature very similar to the Nightmare Rook was a character in a strange picture book called @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg] published long ago in Pitax. In the tales and the picture book, the protagonist encounters the Nightmare Rook and is carried away, only managing to escape by luck. The PCs can secure a copy of Zuddiger’s Picnic by completing the @UUID[.praFCrBA8AMlJRhV] quest. See @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v] of this chapter for more about the book.

To defeat this bloom, a PC must ignore the nightmare itself and confront the watching, ever-present Nightmare Rook. Whenever you describe a PC’s nightmare, but before they wake to endure the resulting spell effect, describe the nature of their nightmare and the fact that a giant black bird looms watching nearby. Give the PC a chance to react to this element of the nightmare. If they confront the rook in any way, the PC can take the following activity. If they don’t confront the bird, describe the nightmare ending in a horrific fashion, much to the watching bird’s delight, and then have the PC awaken to endure the living nightmare’s spell effect.

Confront the Nightmare Rook

  • Concentration

If the PC confronts the Nightmare Rook, ask them to describe how they wish to do so, then select an appropriate skill check to match. For example, a direct physical attack would be modeled by @Check[type:intimidation|dc:40], for example, while a sneaky attack or ambush would use @Check[type:deception|dc:40]. An attempt to appeal to the bird for mercy would use @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:40], using music or song to distract it uses @Check[type:performance|dc:40], and simply sneaking away from the bird’s view would use @Check[type:stealth|dc:40]. Any spellcasting solution would use the corresponding @Check[type:arcana|dc:40], @Check[type:nature|dc:40], @Check[type:occultism|dc:40], or @Check[type:religion|dc:40] skill. Regardless of the skill, the PC attempts a DC 40 check.

  • Critical Success The confrontation catches the Nightmare Rook off guard and frightens it away; the PC awakens with the bloom trophy clutched in a hand, does not suffer the living nightmare’s spell effect, and the bloom is defeated.

  • Success The Nightmare Rook is startled by the PC’s brazen confrontation. It retreats but does not leave. The PC awakens knowing that the nightmares will continue but that the bird’s resolve has been shaken. The PC does not suffer the spell effect of the living nightmare. Reduce the DC to Confront the Nightmare Rook by 2 for all further attempts by any PC.

  • Failure The Nightmare Rook caws in delight at the PC’s failure. The nightmare catches up to the PC, who wakens with a scream and endures the living nightmare’s spell effect.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the living nightmare is particularly harrowing. The PC takes a –4 circumstance penalty to their saving throw against the spell effect or the spell gains a +4 circumstance bonus on its attack roll, as appropriate.

@UUID[Item.x9UldAAwoPhNLPU3]: Black raven feathers pulled from a nightmare, linked to the Nightmare Spire (@UUID[.VooytwmPZQrM1I7N]).

Story Award: Award the PCs 40 XP upon defeating this bloom.

Day 16. The Frozen Bloom.name: Day 16. The Frozen Bloom
Day 16. The Frozen Bloom.text:
An incursion of giants from a frozen graveyard ruled by a deadly, four-armed warlord in Thousandbreaths accompanies a bloom of ice and snow.

Location: A mountain hex.

Bloom: Snow begins falling over this hex regardless of weather conditions in the skies above. The vegetation that blooms and grows here consists of tangles of alpine shrubbery, twisted pine trees, and sheets of thick, slippery lichen. The temperature in this area drops to extreme cold (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 517), and bodies of water in the region freeze over.

An intimidating link to Thousandbreaths rises in this bloom—a towering, 30-foot-tall gravestone made of ice and inscribed with a thousand names manifests at the center of the hex. The language of these names appears to be in each reader’s native tongue, and anyone who thinks to look for their own names or the names of friends or family invariably finds them on the gravestone with eerie speed. To destroy this bloom, the massive ice gravestone must itself be destroyed. The gravestone is 10 feet wide and as hard as stone (Hardness 14, HP 150 [75 BT]). It can be knocked over with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:45] check made as a three-action Manipulate activity; the DC decreases to @Check[type:athletics|dc:35] if the gravestone is below its Broken Threshold. Knocking the gravestone over in this way destroys it. The gravestone is immune to acid damage but has weakness 15 to fire and sonic damage. Cold damage repairs the gravestone for a number of Hit Points equal to the damage the cold would normally have inflicted; the freezing temperatures in the bloom repair damage done to the gravestone at the rate of 15 Hit Points per turn. If destroyed, the icy gravestone topples and shatters into countless razor-sharp shards, each the size of a dagger; these serve as the bloom trophies.

@UUID[Actor.s0BfmFWAhLQkQEbg]

Severe 17

When this bloom opens, a four-armed frost giant named Kargstaad sends six hearty frost giants from Thousandbreaths through to hold the region; Kargstaad himself remains in the @UUID[.CAA97Vaxu4bq0sdN] (area C). These giants are natives of the First World, with skin blue as ice and eyes that glow with white light; they heal wounds at an astounding rate and are stronger and more dangerous than normal frost giants. Once the giants arrive in the Stolen Lands, the urge to chase and crush the delightfully fragile creatures they find proves too much to resist, and they move out of the bloom to explore the Stolen Lands. The wandering band of giants can be encountered anywhere you wish, but most likely the PCs will first hear of them after they attack a small outlying village or start crushing merchant caravans. The giants meet no real opposition as they travel and raid, so they quickly come to see this world’s denizens as trivial challenges. They fearlessly fight to the death until one of them falls, forcing the others to finally appreciate that there is real danger on the Material Plane. At this point, the giants adopt a more defensive pose and make a fighting retreat back toward the bloom.

@UUID[Item.hYWe65P8cQyV2A0F]: Icy gravestone shards, linked to the Frozen Boneyard (@UUID[.CAA97Vaxu4bq0sdN]).

Day 17: The Knurly Briars.name: Day 17: The Knurly Briars
Day 17: The Knurly Briars.text:
Scene

@UUID[Scene.hKVIiPI9XsBMWuf1]

This bloom links the Stolen Lands to the not-quite-abandoned Knurly House.

Location: A hill or plains hex.

Bloom: This bloom manifests in an immense mound of creeping briars and brambles. These hideous, fast-growing brambles extend from the unkempt yard of the Knurly House, the home of a bitter and wretched hag known as the Knurly Witch.

The brambles and briars grow to a height of 15 feet, creating heavy undergrowth (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 514), making it difficult for creatures to move around. Their sharp thorns are mobile and angry, functioning as hazardous terrain. A creature that takes two Move actions in a round in this hex takes [[/r 2d6[piercing]]] damage from the thorns at the end of their turn, or [[/r 4d6[piercing]]] if they take three Move actions.

@UUID[Actor.fbsy6zPV4HjHiis7]

Severe 17

While the Knurly Witch herself doesn’t emerge from her house in the Stolen Lands, her presence can be felt throughout these briars in the form of half-heard cackles, insensible mutterings, and brief glimpses of a strange but towering humanoid shape moving just out of sight through the brambles. These shapes are the “gardeners” of the Knurly Briars, immense and hideously malformed athachs.

As the Knurly Witch’s gardeners, these athachs carry sickles and large bags of strangely pulsating seeds. They move through the brambles, pruning back dead plants and harvesting the eerie red seeds that periodically grow on the vines, only to replant the seeds in the ground. It is this act of pruning and seeding that keeps this bloom growing; if all of the athachs are slain, the bloom reacts by causing the brambles and vines to shriek and whip about in a frenzy. All creatures in the brambles at this time take [[/r 8d6[slashing]]] damage from the thorns (@Check[type:reflex|dc:35|basic:true] save). One round after the death of the last athach, a foul-smelling pod of plant matter erupts from the ground at each location where an athach was slain. A pod takes 1 minute to grow to full size, after which a healthy new athach emerges from it and attempts to return to work. In order to defeat the bloom, all three pods (Hardness 10; HP 50 [BT 25]) must be destroyed before they can spawn. When this happens, the brambles shriek again, but instead of slashing at those caught within them, they melt away into green light and smoke, leaving behind scattered lengths of knotted vines and brambles.

@UUID[Item.IZTr2HwEIRbBSwF2]: Two-foot-long vines of tangled, knotted brambles, linked to the Knurly House (@UUID[.JBCvbybSaiZnm7iK]).

Day 22. Rise of the Mire Worms.name: Day 22. Rise of the Mire Worms
Day 22. Rise of the Mire Worms.text:
A worm-infested bloom of algae, moss, and drooping swamp trees erupts into a remote part of the Hooktongue Slough.

Location: A hex in Hooktongue Slough.

Bloom: The source of this bloom is a hideous swampland in Thousandbreaths known as the Mire, a trackless, soggy realm ruled by a squirming, noxious wizard called the Wriggling Man. This dangerous foe does not enter the Material Plane with this bloom, but he does send four squirming worms cast off from his writhing body into the Stolen Lands.

@UUID[Actor.iD3YlM0QzI2SrjD6]

Severe 17

Upon arriving in the swamp, the four worms grow to immense size and slither their way through the surrounding swampland, consuming any living creature they come across. These four worms travel together at a rate that matches the bloom’s expansion—they can always be encountered in the latest hex to be claimed by this bloom.

These so-called mire worms are hideous segmented creatures with hook-shaped jaws that extend from their rubbery maws when they bite. Each worm is also armed with a jagged, poisonous stinger-tipped tongue. They function identically to azure worms, save that their sting attack is at the tip of their tongue instead the tip of their tail.

Killing the mire worms defeats the bloom and causes their bodies to shrink back down to their original size—the length of a human finger. Although dead, these worms continue to twitch in a most unsettling manner. The worms resemble no known species, but a @Check[type:occultism|dc:40|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo] suggests the worm may be one from a worm that walks.

@UUID[Item.x3r5hAzgXxZN8IFD]: Twitching worms, linked to the Mire (@UUID[.xWZqVDCul4YpCaxc]).

Day 25: The Misbegotten Troll.name: Day 25: The Misbegotten Troll
Day 25: The Misbegotten Troll.text:
This bloom manifests on the site of a large structure or ruin, filling the region with tangles of vegetation.

Location: A hex with a refuge, ruin, or structure that the PCs have already explored but haven’t developed into a settlement or (if possible) haven’t even claimed as part of their kingdom. It’s best if this is a site that is supported by a map from a previous chapter, so that when the PCs come to this bloom, they’ll be on familiar ground yet facing a new enemy. Excellent choices include the hexes containing the @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.W2JjcQj6vysfR53G], the @UUID[JournalEntry.36YItDu6VgX6IRWV.JournalEntryPage.0NksPXFzWv8YI4Jn], @UUID[JournalEntry.OcO78IbhsDP8cUof.JournalEntryPage.RzHbxYswWo3145mp], @UUID[JournalEntry.yGGSDRma9yTWwdeo.JournalEntryPage.jXuSbtaOAWEuRXtr], or the boggard village of @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4].

Bloom: While the majority of the blooms do not bring the more powerful denizens from their connected glades in Thousandbreaths, this one does. Sprouting in an immense cage-like fortress called the Baleful Lantern, this bloom of tangled trees and spiny berry bushes manifests in the Stolen Lands along with the Lantern’s denizen, a hateful and cruel monster known only as the Misbegotten Troll.

The vegetation that radiates out from this bloom grows swiftly, but the core of the bloom is linked to the Misbegotten Troll, who hitched a ride into this world to find fresh new victims to torment and eat.

It’s likely that the PCs will first hear about this bloom after rumors of raids on outlying areas of the kingdom appear. After countless years preying upon fey, the troll is looking for some variety to add to his dinner table—a human or half-orc in particular. Whether the PCs come to confront the troll after he’s first started to raid or after he’s abducted one or more possible meals is left to you to decide. If you want to inject a particular sense of urgency, the troll’s victim could well be an NPC important to the PCs.

  • @UUID[Actor.jUNnWUuiVueOTvHt]
  • @UUID[Actor.ndoXVn6MPPxSJvcC]

Encounter

Severe 17

As the PCs approach the Misbegotten Troll’s new home, it should be obvious that someone has moved into the ruin. Smoke from unseen cook fires billows from the entrance or vents, and numerous territorial markers made of fresh bones, slaughtered locals, or other grisly trophies decorate the approach to the site.

The methods that the Misbegotten Troll uses to defend his new lair from attackers depend greatly on the layout and nature of his new home, and thus no details are given here apart from the villain’s stat block and notes on his basic combat tactics. If his chosen lair is too small to easily admit him physically, he sets up his new home at the location’s entrance. The troll is a loner, but he does keep four particularly large and ill-tempered, black-pelted smilodons handy to serve as guardian beasts. The Misbegotten Troll deploys two of them as guards near the entrance to his lair; the other two remain at his side at all times for additional protection. The troll also wears a short chain threaded through his belt, from which hang several tiny cold iron cages, each of which contains a tormented sprite—Limm’s sisters (see the @UUID[.vT0pu88DsfkvKjOT] quest). The cries and shrieks of these sprites as the troll moves give him an unsettling accompaniment. Since the Misbegotten Troll himself is the living heart of this bloom, his death causes the bloom to collapse.

Treasure: In addition to his glaive and armor, the string of cages carried by the Misbegotten Troll have value. There is one cage per PC, and as long as the four sprites remain trapped, this “chain of lovelies” (as the Misbegotten Troll calls them) is worth 500 gp for its craftsmanship but no one other than the troll himself can jangle the chain to produce any magical effect. While trapped, the sprites cannot take any actions at all. The cages don’t have doors, but it requires success at only a @Check[type:athletics|dc:15|traits:action:force-open] check to force a cage open. Doing so releases the sprite trapped within; if all of the sprites are released, the grateful fey swarm around the PCs with cries of thanks before vanishing back to the First World. As they do, each PC gains the Fey Luck reaction below, usable once only. Freeing the sprites also fulfills the @UUID[.vT0pu88DsfkvKjOT] quest.

@UUID[Item.54HZ0h9J3LGkm4Lt]: Broken cages from the chain of lovelies, linked to the Baleful Lantern (@UUID[.lcZMjY4ZNjcysz2I]).

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.adventure-specific-actions.Item.7WczIXwjOs9raMja] R

  • Fortune
  • Primal

Trigger: You fail or critically fail a saving throw.

Frequency: once

The luck granted to you after freeing the sprites from their cruel cages saves you from an undesirable fate. Adjust a failed saving throw to a success, or a critically failed saving throw to a failed saving throw.

Day 26. War of the High Folly.name: Day 26. War of the High Folly
Day 26. War of the High Folly.text:
The final bloom of the month of destruction opens near the PCs’ capital, unleashing an army of First World monsters upon the kingdom.

Location: A hex adjacent to the PCs’ capital.

Bloom: The final bloom emerges dangerously close to home, at the heart of the PCs’ kingdom and within sight of their capital. This bloom manifests at dawn with a sudden and explosive growth of twisted trees, thorny vines, and evil-looking fungi. Protruding from the center of it is a ghostly image of an impossibly tall alabaster tower atop a hill that looks too round to be natural; this is a projection of a structure in Thousandbreaths called the High Folly—the lair of the black dragon Ilthuliak. A ghostly image of the black wyrm flying in circles around the tower should give the PCs cause to worry, but at this time Ilthuliak has no way to physically strike at the PCs and does not factor into the battle.

As such, this bloom is automatically noticed—if not by the PCs (if they’re not around when this bloom occurs) then by all of their allies back at home. The clamor coming from the tangle of vegetation makes it sound as if a battalion of First World monstrosities hides within, and indeed four armies of murderous beasts, crazed satyrs, giant worms, slavering wyverns, lumbering giants, and flesh-eating plants lurks within, along with a powerful bloom sard.

The armies of First World monsters attack the PCs’ capital an hour before sunset, besieging the city with increasing violence—left unopposed, these armies soon destroy the capital and slaughter everyone who dwells within. On sundown each day that the bloom is active, the PCs’ kingdom must take the Endure Bloom Siege activity below to determine how the capital endures—this is a special Kingdom activity that takes place outside of a Kingdom turn. If the PCs can act quickly and defeat the sard or the First World armies before the first sundown, they have to Endure Bloom Siege only once, but if this bloom is ignored for even a few days, the results can be devastating.

Destroying the bloom requires the PCs to deliver a decisive blow to the monsters, either by defeating the First World armies with their own in a War encounter or by defeating the bloom sard personally in encounter mode. If either the bloom’s armies or the sard are defeated, the bloom itself collapses, leaving behind a three-hundred-foot-diameter scar of barren sand.

Endure Bloom Siege

  • Downtime

If the bloom was active after the previous sundown, the kingdom’s capital must Endure the Bloom Siege.

If the PCs defeated the bloom since the last Endure Bloom Siege activity (either by slaying the rampaging sard or by defeating the bloom army), the result of this Endure Bloom Siege activity is improved one degree of success—this represents the fact that the invaders had less than a full day to do harm.

You can Endure Bloom Siege with a Defense check or a Magic check. Regardless of the kingdom skill chosen, this is a DC 34 check on the first day. The DC increases by 2 every day thereafter until the bloom is defeated or the capital is completely destroyed.

  • Critical Success The capital endures the bloom siege with no damage, but the citizens are still worried. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Success The city’s defenses hold back much of the assault, but damage still occurs. Gain 1 Decay and either destroy one wall or place Rubble into one lot of your choice in the capital’s Urban Grid. If you have no empty lots, reduce one structure in the city to Rubble. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure The city’s defenses strain and threaten to collapse! As success, but place Rubble into three lots of the PCs’ choice in the capital’s Urban Grid. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4]].

  • Critical Failure The city’s defenses are overrun! As failure, but gain 2 Decay, place Rubble into six lots of the PCs’ choice in the capital’s Urban Grid, and increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4+2]].

Ending the Bloom

The bloom sard’s first attack on the region is against an outlying farm, crossroads, or other location of your choice in the hex in which the capital is located. Its first attack occurs at noon on day 26, and it continues to rampage through the region as long as this bloom persists. These attacks panic the populace, and at noon every day after its first attack, until it is defeated or this bloom is finally ended, the kingdom gains 1 Unrest.

  • @UUID[Actor.eD1kydftMIp4CL2K]

Defeating the Sard

Severe 17

If the PCs opt to fight the sard, they track it through the surrounding region automatically. Unless they use magic like teleportation to cut down their travel time, though, it’ll take the PCs [[/r 1d8]] hours to navigate the sard’s trail of destruction through the hinterlands to finally catch up to it; succeeding at a @Check[type:survival|dc:30] check reduces this to only 1 hour. Once confronted, the sard focuses its wrath on the PCs, but if it is reduced to fewer than 50 Hit Points it attempts to flee on its turn. If the sard escapes, it returns to the bloom, recovers, and continues its rampage the next day. Persistent PCs might be able to track it down in its lair in the bloom at your discretion, but only if the sard is slain does the bloom end.

If the PCs defeat the bloom by slaying the sard, the four First World armies become stranded in the region. They no longer make attacks on the capital, but they move through the kingdom and continue to be a nuisance until they are defeated, or until the PCs defeat Nyrissa at the end of this chapter, in which case these stranded armies disperse completely.

Armies

  • @UUID[Actor.2nCGeGTO7HQjEETs]

Defeating the First World Armies

This army is composed of an eclectic mix of fey, beasts, and plants—a supernatural mob of monsters with a wide range of options in battle.

Battlefield: All four of the First World armies attack the PCs’ capital one hour before sundown on Day 26. The capital’s defenders can potentially have the advantage in the battle if there are structures that can be used to fortify armies with ranged attacks. At your option, if the PCs built their capital in a region with natural defenses (such as swamps or rugged mountains), then the First World armies might be penalized by difficult terrain as well.

If the PCs choose not to risk defenders against the army, or if there simply aren’t any armies in the city, and the PCs haven’t broken the morale of the armies by slaying the bloom sard, then the army surges through the capital and the conflict is an automatic defeat for the PCs. Otherwise, the battle plays out as a normal War encounter—see @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD] for Warfare rules.

At your option, the PCs could confront the First World armies in the bloom itself, but doing so should be a much more dangerous fight, with difficult terrain combining with the dim light caused by the strange gloomy haze in the region—and neither of these battlefield terrain features impacts the First World army. Worse, the terrain in the bloom works against invaders, making all of the PC armies in the bloom @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.kingmaker-features.Item.oVhkdym3D6TiTbrN] when a battle begins.

If the PCs win the battle, when you roll to @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD.JournalEntryPage.Sz7W36dIfOpzuRth], on a success or better, the enemy is destroyed and the bloom ends. On a failure or worse, the First World forces retreat, but the bloom doesn’t end—the army takes [[/r 1d3]] days to recover and recruit more monsters from the First World and then attacks once again with its recovered and rebuilt armies. In the meantime, the capital must spend those days continuing to Endure the Bloom Siege (unless the PCs end the bloom by defeating the sard).

If the PCs end the bloom by defeating the army, the bloom sard is stranded on the Material Plane. It becomes a weakened sard (an 18th-level creature) instead and staggers off into the wilds. At your option, the sard (still quite powerful even weakened) can continue to be a danger until the PCs defeat it, but its defeat at this point is not needed to end the bloom.

If the PCs lose the battle, you should @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD.JournalEntryPage.Sz7W36dIfOpzuRth] normally. On a success or better, the First World army retreats back to the bloom but attacks again the next day an hour before sundown. On a failure or worse, the army occupies the capital. From this point on, starting immediately after this failed battle at sunset, each time the kingdom has to Endure the Bloom Siege, they automatically get a critical failure. Once the capital is destroyed, the armies move on to strike at other settlements until the bloom is destroyed.

@UUID[Item.2OZvR3q1KRX0PR6a]: Handfuls of sand taken from the scar left by the bloom’s passing, linked to the High Folly (@UUID[.C8iJTL8Fl1Vf7OxB]).

Day 28. Beware the Jabberwock.name: Day 28. Beware the Jabberwock
Day 28. Beware the Jabberwock.text:
If the PCs don’t force the House at the Edge of Time to manifest on the Material Plane in the forest of Thousand Voices by day 28 of the month of destruction, and Nyrissa has not yet retrieved Briar, then the fey queen sends in her deadliest minion: a lesser jabberwock she grew from blood left over from her ancient battle with the true jabberwock so long ago. The procedure by which she created and raised this lesser jabberwock is a closely guarded secret known only to a few denizens of the First World, for the resulting monster, while not as deadly as a true jabberwock, is a devastating foe nevertheless. It has orders to destroy the PCs—Nyrissa figures that their deaths should render her visions of her own demise moot just as surely as her recovering Briar. If she has already retrieved Briar, she won’t send the lesser jabberwock to attack the PCs; in this case, feel free to have the PCs encounter the monster in Thousandbreaths or in the House at the Edge of Time/Castle of Knives as you wish.

On the dawn of this final event, a strange thing happens in the skies above. Although there’s not a cloud in the sky, roars of thunder echo across the entire Stolen Lands. The thunder comes in diminishing intervals, initially every 10 minutes, but by noon, the thunder booms like the approaching footsteps of an immense creature. Use this ominous event to let the PCs know that something is coming.

Exactly 1 hour after noon, the loudest peal of thunder yet strikes, and with a flash of unsettling green light above the PCs, the boundaries between this world and the First are sundered, and a true monster steps through—a lesser jabberwock. To do this, Nyrissa must first cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.CeSh8QcVnqP5OlLj] on a PC. If she hasn’t observed them via the Horned Hunter’s Fey Conduit, she’ll need a body part or significant item once owned by the PCs. While it’s unlikely she has a body part, she might own an item—any particularly powerful or noteworthy magic item or object a PC had an emotional attachment to will work, and if over the course of this campaign a PC sold or lost such an item, you can rule that Nyrissa’s agents recovered it. (If you do so, make sure to let the PC discover it in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK] later in this chapter!)

@UUID[Actor.XQyXoOe7FCpZilaF]

Extreme 17

A lesser jabberwock is, despite its name, a deadly foe. This hideous reptilian beast stands nearly 30 feet high, with a long, scaly neck, a vaguely draconic body, and a long whiplike tail. Its arms and legs are thin but incredibly strong, ending in sharp talons. Immense draconic wings flap on its back, and its ovoid head is a nightmare of bulging eyes, sharp teeth, and long, thin antennae or whiskers.

If this battle begins in a settlement, the lesser jabberwock’s arrival can potentially damage or destroy a structure—when this battle begins, have one PC attempt a @Check[type:engineering|dc:42|roller:party]. On a failure, the structure closest to the targeted PC becomes damaged, while on a critical failure that structure is destroyed and reduced to @UUID[JournalEntry.BIu4C1T1RR17QNwl.JournalEntryPage.uLknnDCOpL0HvNPq].

Briar: As the battle begins, if the PCs have the sword Briar, it immediately glows with a vibrant green light and wakens to its full capacity, as if it had gained 20 sharpness points. The sword returns to its proper level of awakening once the lesser jabberwock is defeated.

Strategy: The lesser jabberwock uses Intimidation to determine its initiative, then races into the midst of the PCs on the first round of combat to Strike with its bite. On the second round, it Burbles to confuse the PCs that surround it. On following rounds, it makes melee Strikes, preferably against the PC wielding Briar. If the monster is reduced to fewer than 215 hit points, it takes to the air and circles, firing eyes of flame while it heals back up to at least 320 hit points before landing and entering melee again. If denied this level of mobility, the monster simply focuses its fury on single targets, hoping to take the PCs down one at a time. If the monster defeats Briar’s wielder, it claims the weapon and takes to the air. The gate through which Nyrissa sent the creature into the Material Plane is closed, so it must return to the First World via the portal at the Castle of Knives—it flies toward that site with all due haste, eager to return the hated weapon to its mistress. Otherwise, the lesser jabberwock fights to the death.

Day 30. Month’s End.name: Day 30. Month’s End
Day 30. Month’s End.text:
On day 30 of the month of destruction, the event ends in one of two ways.

One or more blooms remain active: Nyrissa can attempt to take the Stolen Lands out of the Material Plane and into the Apology. She must attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:19] to do this if there is only a single active bloom. For each additional bloom that remains active, the DC is reduced by 2. If she’s successful, consult @UUID[.k2Llwg0jHjCQQWfs] for the ramifications of this disastrous development. If she fails, all of the blooms collapse, and she must wait [[/gmroll 1d6]] months before attempting the theft again by causing new blooms. In this event, feel free to re-use some of the blooms presented on the previous pages, or use them as inspiration for designing blooms of your own.

No blooms remain active: The PCs have thwarted Nyrissa’s plans for now, but in time she can start the process all over again. She must wait [[/gmroll 2d6]] months before starting a new month of destruction in order to attempt to take the Stolen Lands again. This should give the PCs plenty of time to begin rebuilding their kingdom, and to take the fight to the nymph’s own realm of Thousandbreaths. During this time, the PCs should either encounter minor blooms of strange plant life, or hear rumors of such, so that they know that while the threat posed by the previous month of destruction has passed, another one could well be looming in the near future. A character who studies one of these smaller blooms can attempt a @Check[type:nature|dc:38] or @Check[type:religion|dc:38] check can confirm that the danger has only been stalled—a critical success at this check gives the character the exact number of months remaining before Nyrissa starts a brand new bloom.

Part 2: A Thousand Breaths.name: Part 2: A Thousand Breaths
Part 2: A Thousand Breaths.text:
The PCs should be 18th level before they enter Thousandbreaths.

As this chapter begins, the PCs should be aware that their kingdom is under attack by something beyond the mortal realm. The manifestation of the blooms, the incursions of strange monsters, and even the appearance of the strange trophies after a bloom is defeated all point to the First World as the source of the dangers.

Thousandbreaths

There are many events in Part 1 of this adventure that should convince the PCs that some force from the First World has taken an interest in the Stolen Lands—speaking with the nereid Evindra, the pixie @UUID[.vT0pu88DsfkvKjOT], or interrogating captured prisoners from blooms will confirm this. They can also @UUID[.Z9tXO2BefaG40wFP] the topic in libraries they’ve constructed in their kingdom, or they might even know about it from using skills to Recall Knowledge. Eventually, the PCs should learn that if they wish to confront their enemy, they must travel to a specific part of the First World called Thousandbreaths—but the more they know about this realm beforehand, the better their chances will be.

Traveling to Thousandbreaths.name: Traveling to Thousandbreaths
Traveling to Thousandbreaths.text:
Unbloomed Encounters

If the PCs make it to Thousandbreaths before the month of destruction concludes, they’ll face more dangerous encounters here, but if they wait too long in hopes of defeating more blooms, they run the risk that Nyrissa might absorb their kingdom. Eight of the nine glade encounters detailed here (areas B–I) are presented with the assumption that their associated bloom has manifested and been defeated, and are thus Moderate 18 encounters. If a glade’s associated bloom hasn’t manifested or hasn’t been defeated by the PCs, though, some of the creatures and energies that would have been expended on that bloom remain active in the glade and it becomes a Severe 18 encounter. Notes on what to add to each glade encounter to make it a Severe 18 encounter appear at the end of the encounter in an “Unbloomed” entry.

If all of the creatures in a glade encounter are defeated before the glade’s associated bloom manifests during the month of destruction, that bloom does not manifest at all when its day comes.

When @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD] founded Thousandbreaths, it existed fully in the First World, but after she was punished by the Eldest, they shed this domain from that plane. Today, Thousandbreaths exists as its own demiplane, where much of the realities of the First World hold sway, yet it serves also as a prison from which Nyrissa cannot stray for long.

Due to its nature as an obscure demiplane, travel to Thousandbreaths from another plane is difficult. The PCs could use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ] to travel there but only if they’ve fully researched Thousandbreaths by gaining at least 18 Research Points. Even then, they’ll need a special tuning fork to travel to the realm—although a copy of @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg] can function in place of such a focus for spellcasting. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.U13bC0tNgrlHoeTK] can create a portal to Thousandbreaths, although as an uncommon 10th-level spell, the PCs might not have access to it.

A fixed portal does exist that links Thousandbreaths and the Material Plane—the main entrance to the ruins known as the @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9] deep in the forest of Thousand Voices. This portal flared open for a few months when Nyrissa’s attention first came to the stolen lands about two decades ago (it was at this time that Karn Zuddiger stumbled through the portal while exploring the forest, emerging just before it closed to go on to pen Zuddiger’s Picnic), but has remained inert since then. It’s not until the blooms begin during Part 1 of this chapter that the Castle of Knives portal opens back up. As long as the blooms remain active, the portal remains impossible to miss—any who approach the Castle of Knives see it as a vine-shrouded rent in reality. While the PCs won’t learn of this portal’s activation while researching Thousandbreaths, they can certainly infer its existence, but it’s most likely they’ll learn about it from one of their fey allies such as Evindra or Limm Ticklewing. Of course, unless the PCs carry three different Bloom trophies with them, they won’t be able to pass through this portal at all.

Once the blooms begin, a remarkable transformation takes place in the castle’s ruins—the castle appears as a strange structure of sharp towers and confusing architecture of dozens of colors that seem strangely too vibrant for the surroundings. The entire castle is surrounded by a wrought iron fence that contains a single gate flanked by statues of beautiful women. The transformation lasts until the PCs uproot Nyrissa’s realm, but the iron gate itself continues to function as a portal to Thousandbreaths as long as that realm continues to exist as a demiplane.

Regardless of the method the PCs use to travel to Thousandbreaths, they always appear in the same place: the Byway (@UUID[.2Z65BXwMzTkQ9dRZ])

Exploring Thousandbreaths.name: Exploring Thousandbreaths
Exploring Thousandbreaths.text:
Scene

@UUID[Scene.UBHZsJUUrunIVYXl]

A Restless Land

Thousandbreaths is a demiplane that lies adjacent to the Material Plane, but many of the realm’s features still adhere to those of its source—the First World. As Thousandbreaths is under Nyrissa’s direct control, other realities exist in this demiplane as well.

Eternal Twilight: It is always twilight in Thousandbreaths. No matter what time the PCs enter and how long they stay there, the sun never sets (although in fact time is unaffected and passes normally—the time of day is merely fixed in place). This ambient light provides dim light in the realm.

Glades: A number of large clearings exist in Thousandbreaths—these are known as glades, and each contains a unique encounter area detailed below. Each glade is linked to one of the blooms that manifests in the Stolen Lands—a character carrying a bloom trophy from the linked area receives a +1 status bonus on attack rolls, weapon damage rolls, skill checks, saving throws, and ability checks while in that glade.

Sleeping: Visitors who sleep in Thousandbreaths are subjected to @UUID[RollTable.RyETqIR5yFNv4BmP] if the Nightmare Rook (see @UUID[.VooytwmPZQrM1I7N]) still lives or if the @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB] bloom hasn’t been defeated.

Sounds: These are the voices: the thousand voices of Thousandbreaths, the source of the region’s name. In truth, there are far more than a mere thousand breaths in Thousandbreaths, as the disembodied voices are from those taken and remade by the queen, cries of helplessness in a pitiless and unending twilight. Beyond the screams there are other sounds: weeping, singing of children’s rhymes, shouts of anger, feral cries, and howls—PCs who listen too closely might even hear familiar voices that could well sound like villains or friends who have died or gone missing over the course of the Kingmaker Adventure Path. The sounds of Thousandbreaths cause a –2 circumstance penalty on all Perception checks made to hear things.

The Woods: Moving through the woods without using the paths and rivers is dangerous. The off-path woods are treated as greater difficult terrain and hazardous terrain, and characters take [[/r 1d6]] piercing damage for each Move action they take when they travel through these thorny, tangled woods.

Effect

@UUID[Item.axydAfNb3J8hMFqI]

As your players explore the glades, you can use this effect on characters carrying the glade's linked trophy to provide them with a bonus to attack rolls, weapon damage rolls, skill checks, and saving throws.

Paths and Rivers

Travel through Thousandbreaths is easiest via its network of paths and rivers, yet navigating them is nerve-wracking. Eyes blink from the dark of the forest, lights are dim and seem to have trouble illuminating beyond the paths, and even stranger lights dance and twitch in the sky above, almost as if the stars can’t decide on their routes through the darkening sky.

Two types of passages exist within the realm of Thousandbreaths—paths and rivers. Travel along a path is possible in both directions, but travel along a river always leads downstream—even if a person attempts to follow a river upstream by flying above it or reached is always the one they would have reached by moving downstream. The rivers always flow away from @UUID[.JcAvEG7qrQeNWnPF] toward @UUID[.hwO3Kbh0Izx5mQtF].

Any character who tries to fly above the top of the wood’s trees discovers an unsettling truth about the reality of this realm—there seems to be no world above the canopy. No matter how high they fly, the tops of the trees extend to what seems to be 200 feet above. Only Nyrissa and the Nightmare Rook (see @UUID[.VooytwmPZQrM1I7N]) can actually travel above the treetops of Thousandbreaths.

Regardless of the speed or method used to navigate a path or river, it always takes [[/gmroll 1d4]] hours to reach the next glade. Each time the PCs use a path to travel, roll a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]; on a success, the pathway is perilous in some way—roll on the Pathway Perils table below to determine in what way.

@UUID[RollTable.RbXf5uSHPzBZrefW]
[[/r 1d4]]Result
1This is a grassy trail, the edges of which are littered with statues of curious creatures that are at once human and animal. The trees here have an unsettlingly fleshy look about them, with parts of people woven or grafted into them, some of which speak nonsense to the PCs as they pass. At one point during the journey, each character must attempt a @Check[type:will|dc:38|traits:emotion,mental,primal] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ] by these voices for [[/gmroll 1d6]] rounds (this is an emotion, mental, primal effect).
2This path is narrow, only 10 feet wide, with thorny branches hanging low over it. It takes [[/gmroll 2d4]] hours to reach the next glade.
3The edges of this path grow thick with strange flowers that seem to writhe and move on their own. Each flower has a tangle of tentacle-like vines hanging down from its stem. These plants are dangerous and exude @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.X6vNtRjyHIuN7vqj] into the path once the PCs are halfway down the path to their destination, exposing the entire party to the poisonous effect.
4This 10-foot-wide path seems to be a barely used animal track, although countless bloated animal carcasses lie strewn amid the undergrowth along both sides of the path. Characters who travel this path are exposed to a virulent form of bubonic plague (Pathfinder Gamemastery Guide 118, but this is an 18th-level disease with a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:38] save).

Uprooting Thousandbreaths.name: Uprooting Thousandbreaths
Uprooting Thousandbreaths.text:
Uprooting DC Reductions
AreaGuardianReduction
B4 Storm-Struck Arboreals–1
CKargstaad–2
DNightmare Rook–2
EImmense Mandragora–1
GThe Wriggling Man (area K17)–4
HThe Knurly Witch–4
IDestroy the Baleful Lantern–1
JIlthuliak–4

Nyrissa, despite her power, does not actually have within herself the ability to reshape and maintain the entire realm of Thousandbreaths. She can create glades and their contents, but in order for them to maintain their shape, each glade must be tethered to a powerful entity so full of life that its presence acts as an anchor.

By defeating anchors, the PCs weaken the underlying structure of Thousandbreaths and cause it to drift further and further from the First World. Each time they defeat all of the guardians of a glade (with the exception of @UUID[.FX3GDvDIGbQTaR5k]), there’s a chance that the defeat is enough to cause Thousandbreaths to tumble cataclysmically into the Material Plane.

When the PCs defeat all the guardians of a glade, attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:20]. On a success, Thousandbreaths is uprooted. On a failure, this DC is reduced by a value depending on the power of the defeated anchor (see the adjacent table), so that the next flat check is against a lower DC. If the PCs defeat all of the anchors, Thousandbreaths is automatically uprooted. Slaying an anchor’s guardian defeats it, as does transporting a guardian out of Thousandbreaths, for once a guardian is absent from this demiplane—even if for only a second—the tether they provide snaps. GivenWh a year, Nyrissa could restore a defeated anchor, but for the context of this campaign, you can assume a defeated anchor remains defeated.

If Thousandbreaths is uprooted, it manifests fully within the forest of Thousand Voices in the Stolen Lands, its glades appearing as different areas in the forest. When this cataclysmic event occurs, the sound of a thousand screams tears through the air, a horrific noise as the realm expels its thousand breaths at once. The denizens of the glades are traumatized by this event, and all surviving guardians become slowed 1 for the next 24 hours.

All of the otherworldly elements of Thousandbreaths vanish when it uproots, but for the most part the general natures of the encounters in unvisited glades should be relatively unchanged. More importantly, once Thousandbreaths is uprooted, Nyrissa can no longer use the Apology to absorb the Stolen Lands, as uprooting Thousandbreaths causes all active blooms in the Stolen Lands to end instantly (although any creatures active in those blooms remain in the area where the bloom was once located).

Only the House at the Edge of Time remains within what was once the demiplane—the plane’s borders now encompass only the glade that contains that structure and its surrounding lake. The PCs can still come and go via the portal at the Castle of Knives or other methods of planar travel, but now the Byway (area A) manifests at the lake’s edge near the bridge that leads to the House’s isle.

Given time, Nyrissa may be able to rebuild Thousandbreaths through the use of create demiplane, but once Thousandbreaths is uprooted, her plan to absorb the Stolen Lands is over. At this point the Stolen Lands are safe from her machinations—yet the PCs themselves most certainly are not, and in this development, the nymph queen begins a new campaign of vengeance against the PCs; see page 459 for more on this development.

Story Award: Should the PCs manage to uproot Thousandbreaths and cast the demiplane into the Material Plane, award them 120 XP.

A. The Byway.name: A. The Byway
A. The Byway.text: All who travel to Thousandbreaths from other planes arrive here, at the Byway. This archway is formed by a pair of beautiful women shaped in iron. Each statue raises one hand toward the other, forming an arch; the other hand holds high a sword that bears a striking resemblance to @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]. The first time Briar is brought through this gate, it gains a Sharpness Point—as this occurs, both it and the blades of the statues momentarily glow with green light. Nyrissa notices this effect and thus knows when Briar enters Thousandbreaths, but she does not react. If the sword is in the hands of her agents, they’ll bring it to her soon enough, and if it is in the hands of her enemies, she does not want to confront them and instead hopes that the various perils of Thousandbreaths finish them off.

B. Watchers on the Whirling Shore.name: B. Watchers on the Whirling Shore
B. Watchers on the Whirling Shore.text:
A broad lake of dark water fills the majority of this forest glen, leaving a fifteen-foot-wide shoreline. Black swans glide along the lake’s surface, apparently unimpressed by the immense but strangely silent whirlpool that churns at the lake’s center. Along the forest edge, many of the trees seem to be dying or dead.

The swans are simply swans, and while the lake’s vortex is powerful (functioning identically to the one detailed in the @UUID[.AMmC4r0Kija5A9XZ] bloom, but only with a diameter of 100 feet), it doesn’t threaten those who wade along the shores. The circular lake itself is 200 feet across.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.U4QON5JFeGRdAZ3k], linked to the @UUID[.AMmC4r0Kija5A9XZ] bloom.

@UUID[Actor.BJbe6BzLSIx8Jsix]

Moderate 18

The true threat here comes from the immense arboreals that guard the lake’s shores. Although these lightning-scarred guardians might look to the casual observer like dead trees, they are very much alive and quickly move to attack anyone that passes nearby. There are four of these storm-struck arboreals in all—one stands guard next to each exit from the lake glade.

If a storm-struck arboreal can’t reach the PCs, it uses its electricity spells to attack, making sure to catch other arboreals in the area of effect if it can to provide healing. The storm-struck arboreals fight to the death.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.AMmC4r0Kija5A9XZ] bloom has not been defeated, the four elder elemental tsunamis from it lurk within the waters of this lake—these elementals work with the storm-struck arboreals to defend the glade.

C. The Frozen Boneyard.name: C. The Frozen Boneyard
C. The Frozen Boneyard.text:
Snow falls steadily in this forest glade, which appears to be an ominously oversized cemetery. Dozens of ten-foot-tall headstones rise from the snow, leaning awkwardly as if the ground below had grown unstable. An old tower leans precariously against the supportive branches of several trees at one end of the glade, while an immense marble vault looms at the other, at the edge of a frozen lake.

The temperature in this glade is extreme cold (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 518). Nyrissa rarely comes to this grove anymore; she has little interest in this frigid corner of Thousandbreaths and leaves its care to Kargstaad, a foul-tempered, four-armed frost giant who lives in the vault at the edge of the boneyard’s frozen lake. This glade, despite the appearance of a frozen cemetery, is not an actual cemetery—Nyrissa simply found the appearance of a frozen burial ground soothing when she was in her darker moods.

The tower is little more than a spiral stair built into a 200-foot-tall circular stone shell. It is in dreadful repair but is in no danger of collapsing. The stairs end at a dizzying vantage point in the open rooftop that somehow still doesn’t allow a view over the treetops.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.hYWe65P8cQyV2A0F], linked to the @UUID[.0KoVNo4JXSXcViBI].

@UUID[Actor.wJDtBtvRtyxtyqHS]

Moderate 18

Kargstaad and his giant followers dwell here, eternally provided for by the glade when it comes to hunting for food or water. Collected as trophies ages ago by Nyrissa, these giants know little but their lives in this glade. When this glade’s bloom opens, Kargstaad sends his minions through to protect the bloom, but the giants, starved for entertainment, quickly abandon it. Once the bloom closes, Kargstaad knows his giants have failed him, and the arrival of the PCs gives him an opportunity to smooth over this failure if only he can capture them for his mistress.
